title: estimating the domain of attraction via union of continuous families of lyapunov estimates
keywords: attracteur;desigualdad matricial lineal;polynomial system;dominio atraccion;funcion lyapunov;convex programming;point equilibre;lyapunov function;programmation convexe;attractor;equilibrium point;atractor;punto equilibrio;linear matrix inequality;parameter dependent estimate;fonction lyapunov;lmi;stability condition;inegalite matricielle lineaire;domaine attraction;article;domain of attraction;programacion convexa
abstract: This paper proposes a new approach to estimate the domain of attraction of equilibrium points of polynomial systems. The idea consists of estimating the domain of attraction via the union of a continuous family of Lyapunov estimates rather than via one Lyapunov estimate only as done in existing methods. This family is obtained through a convex LMI optimization by deriving a stability condition which takes simultaneously into account all considered Lyapunov functions. Moreover, inner approximations of the union of this family via a set with simple shape are also derived.
fos: equilibrium point;mathematical optimization;mathematical analysis;convex optimization;linear matrix inequality;lyapunov function;lyapunov equation;control theory;mathematics;lyapunov redesign;lyapunov exponent;attractor

title: delay robustness of nonlinear internet congestion control schemes
keywords: automatic control;metodo lyapunov;lyapunov methods;control systems;optimisation;delay robust control internet algebra quantum computing automatic control mathematics matrix decomposition centralized control design methodology;congestion trafic;mathematics;funcion lyapunov;metodologia;methods;primal decomposition;congestion trafico;convex programming;delay effect;uncertainty;lyapunov function;gradient method;nonlinear control systems;bandwidth allocation;gestion trafic;primal dual method;telecommunication congestion control;efecto retardo;delay effects;noncommensurate communication delays;programmation convexe;robust control;traffic management;methode primale duale;internet congestion control;lyapunov;telecommunication congestion control bandwidth allocation delays gradient methods nonlinear control systems optimisation stability;methodologie;delai transmission;transmission time;stability;asignacion de banda pasante;optimal control;optimization problem;methode gradient;nonlinear systems;nonlinear internet congestion control;lyapunov method;internet;metodo primal dual;traffic congestion;algebra;fonction lyapunov;metodo gradiente;mathematical programming;matrix decomposition;commande non lineaire;robustesse;effet retard;retard;gestion trafico;gradient methods;communication delay;non linear control;robustness;optimization;noncommensurate communication delays nonlinear internet congestion control primal decomposition dual decomposition optimization bandwidth allocation gradient method;centralized control;nonlinear system;methodology;communication system control;quantum computing;retraso;plazo transmision;programmation mathematique;methode lyapunov;robustness delay effects internet congestion control lyapunov methods nonlinear systems;dual decomposition;programacion matematica;allocation bande passante;delays;control no lineal;robustez;design methodology;programacion convexa
abstract: Several nonlinear Internet congestion control schemes have been proposed in the previous years based on primal and dual decompositions of convex yet centralized optimization problems that describe the bandwidth allocation problem. This design methodology uses (sub)gradient methods for the design of node/link dynamics and guarantees nominal functionality for arbitrary system sizes. In this technical note we analyze the robustness of such nonlinear schemes to the presence of multiple, non-commensurate (heterogeneous) communication delays.
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;nonlinear system;lyapunov function;control theory;mathematics

title: deriving sufficient conditions for global asymptotic stability of delayed neural networks via nonsmooth analysis
keywords: numerical stability;nonsmooth analysis equilibrium point global asymptotic stability lipschitzian functions neural networks;algorithms computer simulation models theoretical neural networks computer numerical analysis computer assisted signal processing computer assisted time factors;lipschitz function;neural networks;global asymptotic stability;neural nets;fonction lipschitz;point equilibre;activation function;stabilite asymptotique;analisis non regular;lipschitzian functions;cellular neural network;funcion lipschitz;positive definite;asymptotic stability;nonsmooth analysis;equilibrium point;lipschitzian function sufficient condition derivation global asymptotic stability nonsmooth analysis delayed cellular neural network stability string unification feedback matrix lmi approach equilibrium point;punto equilibrio;sufficient conditions asymptotic stability neural networks delay effects neurofeedback jacobian matrices councils mathematics stability analysis lyapunov method;neural nets asymptotic stability delays jacobian matrices;red celular;cell network;reseau cellulaire;sufficient conditions asymptotic stability neural networks cellular neural networks delay effects stability analysis output feedback state feedback mathematics neurofeedback;analyse non lisse;spectral properties;estabilidad asintotica;reseau neuronal;neural networks computer;jacobian matrices;existence and uniqueness;nonsingularity sufficient conditions global asymptotic stability delayed neural networks nonsmooth analysis lipschitz property existence results uniqueness results equilibrium point spectral properties generalized jacobian delayed feedback matrix;red neuronal;delays;neural network;delays neural nets numerical stability jacobian matrices asymptotic stability
abstract: In this paper, we obtain new sufficient conditions ensuring existence, uniqueness, and global asymptotic stability (GAS) of the equilibrium point for a general class of delayed neural networks (DNNs) via nonsmooth analysis, which makes full use of the Lipschitz property of functions defining DNNs. Based on this new tool of nonsmooth analysis, we first obtain a couple of general results concerning the existence and uniqueness of the equilibrium point. Then those results are applied to show that existence assumptions on the equilibrium point in some existing sufficient conditions ensuring GAS are actually unnecessary; and some strong assumptions such as the boundedness of activation functions in some other existing sufficient conditions can be actually dropped. Finally, we derive some new sufficient conditions which are easy to check. Comparison with some related existing results is conducted and advantages are illustrated with examples. Throughout our paper, spectral properties of the matrix (A + Atau) play an important role, which is a distinguished feature from previous studies. Here, A and Atau are, respectively, the feedback and the delayed feedback matrix defining the neural network under consideration.
fos: equilibrium point;mathematical optimization;mathematical analysis;cellular neural network;computer science;machine learning;control theory;mathematics;positive-definite matrix;lipschitz continuity;activation function;artificial neural network;numerical stability

title: a new approach to exponential stability analysis of neural networks with time-varying delays
keywords: desigualdad matricial lineal;neural networks;activation function;exponential stability;delay system;global exponential stability;equilibrium point;time varying system;linear matrix inequality;systeme a retard;stabilite exponentielle;systeme parametre variable;lipschitz continuity;inegalite matricielle lineaire;time varying delay systems;sistema parametro variable;sistema con retardo;reseau neuronal;time varying delay;red neuronal;estabilidad exponencial;neural network
abstract: This paper considers the problem of exponential stability analysis of neural networks with time-varying delays. The activation functions are assumed to be globally Lipschitz continuous. A linear matrix inequality (LMI) approach is developed to derive sufficient conditions ensuring the delayed neural network to have a unique equilibrium point, which is globally exponentially stable. The proposed LMI conditions can be checked easily by recently developed algorithms solving LMIs. Examples are provided to demonstrate the reduced conservativeness of the proposed results.
entities: activation function;artificial neural network;assumed;biological neural networks;checking (action);linear matrix inequality;neural network simulation;social inequality;algorithm;exponential
journal: Neural networks : the official journal of the International Neural Network Society
fos: equilibrium point;mathematical optimization;linear matrix inequality;computer science;machine learning;calculus;control theory;mathematics;lipschitz continuity;activation function;exponential stability;artificial neural network

title: stabilizability of bimodal piecewise linear systems with continuous vector field
keywords: controllability;linear system;piecewise linear systems;conferenceobject;vector field;stabilizability;piecewise linear system;bimodal systems
abstract: This paper studies the open-loop stabilization problem for bimodal systems with continuous vector field. It is based on the earlier work of the authors on the controllability problem for the same class of systems. A full characterization of stabilizability is established by presenting algebraic necessary and sufficient conditions. It turns out that this system class inherits the relationship between controllability and stabilizability of linear systems.
authors: M. Kanat Camlibel;W. P. M. H. Heemels;J. M. Schumacher
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;control theory;mathematics

title: adaptive lag synchronization of memristive neural networks with mixed delays
abstract: This paper investigates the lag synchronization of memristive neural networks (MNNs) with mixed delays via adaptive control. Based on the switching jump properties of memristors and the assumption that the activation functions are bounded, three lemmas are derived first to deal with the theoretical analysis difficulties caused by the existences of time delays and time lag. By designing a series of suitable adaptive controllers, we prove that the considered MNNs can achieve asymptotic lag synchronization, exponential lag synchronization, and finite-time lag synchronization, respectively. Adaptive control can avoid the large control gains very well, and adaptive control can be used even when the system parameters are unknown. Moreover, extra calculations are not required to determine the appropriate control gains. Numerical simulations are presented to verify the effectiveness of the obtained theoretical results.
entities: activation function;artificial neural network;memristor;numerical linear algebra;simulation;time complexity
authors: Chuan Yong Chen;Lixiang Li;Haipeng Peng;Yixian Yang
fos: memristor;computer science;distributed computing;artificial neural network;control theory;bounded function;adaptive control;synchronization;exponential function;jump;lag

title: lyapunov functionals for automata networks defined by cyclically monotone functions
keywords: automata networks;68r99;period;red automata;funcion lyapunov;lyapunov functionals;lyapunov function;fonction monotone;cycle limite;68q80;monotone function;periodo;cyclically monotone functions;comportement transitoire;funcion monotona;reseau automate;periode;fonction lyapunov;limit cycle;monotonic function;transient behavior periods;ciclo limite;automaton network
abstract: For automata networks with dynamics given by $x( t + 1 ) = f( Ax( t ) - b )$, where A is symmetric and f is cyclically monotone, it is proved that there exists a Lyapunov functional $( H( x( t ) ) )_{t\geqq 1} $ that increases with t along the orbit. This allows one to study the finite limit cycles (which are of length one or two), the transient behavior in the finite case, and also to write down explicit integral functionals. The existence of $( H( x( t ) ) )$ is important for a physical approach to the study of these automata networks. The condition that f be cyclically monotone in $\mathbb{R}$ is equivalent to f increasing and is usually used in applications to computer sciences.
fos: combinatorics;mathematical analysis;discrete mathematics;monotonic function;mathematics

title: passivity based control of a class of hamiltonian systems with nonholonomic constraints
keywords: computacion informatica;stabilization;grupo de excelencia;nonholonomic systems;ciencias basicas y experimentales;port hamiltonian systems
abstract: This paper is concerned with state and output feedback stabilization of a class of port-Hamiltonian systems with nonholonomic constraints. First we study canonical forms for port-Hamiltonian systems with nonholonomic constraints. Second, we give a new state feedback stabilization method by using non-smooth Hamiltonian functions via generalized canonical transformations. Third, we propose a dynamic output feedback stabilization method without measuring the velocity based on the corresponding state feedback result. Numerical examples demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.
entities: block cipher mode of operation;hamiltonian (quantum mechanics);numerical method;velocity (software development)
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;control theory;mathematics

title: finite-time stabilization control for discontinuous time-delayed networks: new switching design
keywords: discontinuous activation;kakutani s fixed point theorem;differential inclusions;time delayed neural networks;switching controller;finite time stabilization
abstract: This paper discusses the finite-time stabilization problem for time-varying delayed neural networks (DNNs) with discontinuous activation functions. By using fixed point theory and set-valued analysis, we establish the existence theorem of equilibrium point. In order to stabilize the states of this class of discontinuous DNNs in finite time, we design two different kinds of switching controllers which are described by discontinuous functions. Under the framework of Filippov solutions, several new and effective criteria are derived to realize finite-time stabilization of discontinuous DNNs based on the famous finite-time stability theory. Besides, the upper bounds of the settling time of stabilization are estimated. Numerical examples are finally provided to illustrate the correctness of the proposed design method and theoretical results.

title: exponential passivity analysis of stochastic neural networks with leakage, distributed delays and markovian jumping parameters
keywords: distributed delay;leakage delay;exponential passivity analysis;markovian jumping parameter;stochastic neural network
abstract: This paper deals with the problem of exponential passivity of Markovian jumping stochastic neural networks with leakage and distributed delays. By constructing a proper Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional, utilizing the free-weighting matrix method and some stochastic analysis techniques, we deduce new delay-dependent sufficient conditions that ensure the passivity of the proposed model. These sufficient conditions are computationally efficient and they can be solved numerically by linear matrix inequality (LMI) toolbox in Matlab. Finally, numerical examples are given to verify the effectiveness and the applicability of the proposed results.
authors: S. Senthilraj;Rubesh Raja;Quanxin Zhu;Rajendran Samidurai;Zhangsong Yao
fos: stochastic neural network;mathematical optimization;computer science;machine learning;control theory

title: adding an integration with prescribed local behavior
keywords: lyapunov methods;feedforward;lyapunov methods matrix decomposition approximation methods symmetric matrices equations vectors backstepping;approximation method;closed loop systems;nonlinear control systems;stabilization;feedforward form;stability;symmetric matrices;feedback;lyapunov method;feedforward form stabilization lyapunov design forwarding first order approximation;first order;design method;vectors;backstepping;matrix decomposition;lyapunov design;control system synthesis;feedforward form feedback form nonlinear control techniques lyapunov design methods forwarding backstepping methods continuous control law stabilization local behaviour closed loop system;non linear control;stability closed loop systems control system synthesis feedback feedforward nonlinear control systems;approximation methods;forwarding;first order approximation
abstract: Among the non-linear control techniques, some Lyapunov design methods (Forwarding / Backstepping) take advantage of the structure of the system (Feedforward-form / Feedback-form) to formulate a continuous control law which stabilizes globally and asymptotically the equilibrium. In addition to stabilization, we focus on the local behaviour of the closed loop system, providing conditions under which we can predetermine the behaviour around the origin for Feedforward systems.

title: extensions of “padé discretization for linear systems with polyhedral lyapunov functions” for generalized jordan structures
keywords: eigenvalues and eigenfunctions;lyapunov methods;linear systems;eigenvalues pade discretization polyhedral lyapunov functions generalized jordan structures linear time invariant systems diagonal pade approximations continuous time system matrix;matrix algebra approximation theory continuous time systems eigenvalues and eigenfunctions linear systems lyapunov methods;matrix algebra;approximation theory;continuous time systems;lyapunov methods approximation methods eigenvalues and eigenfunctions switches piecewise linear approximation linear systems stability analysis;preservation of lyapunov functions discretization nontrivial jordan blocks pade approximations polyhedral lyapunov functions
abstract: Recently, we showed that certain types of polyhedral Lyapunov functions for linear time-invariant systems, are preserved by diagonal Padé approximations, under the assumption that the continuous-time system matrix Ac has distinct eigenvalues. In this technical note, we show that this result also holds true in the case that Ac has non-trivial Jordan blocks.

title: exponential stability of interval dynamical systems with quadratic nonlinearity
keywords: metodo lyapunov;metodo directo;systeme dynamique non lineaire;quadratic nonlinearity;nonlinear dynamical systems;exponential stability;nonlinear dynamical system;dynamic system;lyapunov method;stabilite exponentielle;lyapunov direct method;attraction domain estimation;attraction;aritmetica intervalo;interval arithmetic;atraccion;arithmetique intervalle;methode directe;methode lyapunov;direct method;estabilidad exponencial
abstract: This article proposes an approach for investigating the exponential stability of a nonlinear interval dynamical system with the nonlinearity of a quadratic type on the basis of the Lyapunov’s direct method. It also constructs an inner estimate of the attraction domain to the origin for the system under consideration.
fos: direct method;mathematical analysis;dynamical system;calculus;control theory;mathematics;interval arithmetic;exponential stability

title: hinfinity state feedback control for generalized continuous/discrete time-delay system
keywords: condicion existencia;desigualdad matricial lineal;systeme commande;sistema control;boucle reaction etat;concepcion sistema;control h infinito;schur complement;state feedback;discrete time;generation time;delay system;time delay;delayed system;condition suffisante;control system;linear matrix inequality;condicion suficiente;systeme a retard;system design;condition existence;controller design;bucle realimentacion estado;inegalite matricielle lineaire;sufficient condition;h control;sistema con retardo;existence condition;state feedback control;h infinite control;conception systeme;commande h infini
abstract: In this paper, we consider the problem of designing H^~ state feedback controller for the generalized time-delay systems with delayed states and control inputs in continuous and discrete time cases, respectively. The generalized time-delay system problems are solved on the basis of linear matrix inequality (LMI) technique considering time delays. The sufficient condition for the existence of controller and H^~ state feedback controller design methods are presented. Also, using some changes of variables and Schur complements, the obtained sufficient condition can be rewritten as an LMI form in terms of transformed variables. The proposed controller design method can be extended into the problem of robust H^~ state feedback controller design method easily.
fos: control engineering;discrete time and continuous time;linear matrix inequality;control system;calculus;control theory;mathematics;schur complement;generation time;systems design

title: exponential stability of nonlinear switched delay systems
keywords: exponential stability;switched delay systems;linear matrix inequalities
abstract: In this paper, the exponential stability of a class of nonlinear switched systems with time-varying disturbances is considered. A new piecewise time-varying Lyapunov functionals which are decreasing at switching times by construction are introduced to investigate exponential stability of switched delay systems, sufficient conditions expressed as linear matrix inequalities are obtained.
fos: exponential error;mathematical optimization;control theory;mathematics;exponential stability

title: on the almost global stability of invariant sets
abstract: For a given invariant set of a dynamical system, it is known that the existence of a Lyapunov-type density function, called Lyapunov density or Rantzer's density function, may imply the convergence of almost all solutions to the invariant set, in other words, the almost global stability (also called almost everywhere stability) of the invariant set. For discrete-time systems, related results in literature assume that the state space is compact and the invariant set has a local basin of attraction. We show that these assumptions are redundant. Using the duality between Frobenius-Perron and Koopman operators, we provide a Lyapunov density theorem for discrete-time systems without assuming the compactness of the state space or any local attraction property of the invariant set. As a corollary to this new discrete-time Lyapunov density theorem, we provide a continuous-time Lyapunov density theorem which can be used as an alternative to Rantzer's original theorem, especially where the solutions are known to exist globally.

title: linear systems subject to input saturation and time delay: finite-gain $l{\lowercasep}$-stabilization
keywords: delay control;finite gain stability;ecuacion estocastica;continuous time;equation differentielle;stochastic equation;input saturation;funcion lyapunov;equation a retard;lyapunov function;control diferido;34h05;stabilization;temps lineaire;saturacion entrada;differential equation;93d05;temps continu;lyapunov functions;tiempo continuo;control lineal;tiempo lineal;delay system;equation stochastique;commande bornee;linear system;time delay;delay equation;sistema independiente del tiempo;ecuacion diferencial;stability;upper bound;93d15;retroaccion;systeme a retard;estabilizacion;control limitado;fonction lyapunov;retroaction;delay independent system;linear time;commande a retard;feedback regulation;commande lineaire;ecuacion retardada;systeme independant du retard;temps retard;stabilisation;bounded control;delay time;sistema con retardo;93d25;stabilite;borne superieure;linear control;tiempo retardo;saturation entree;time delay systems;estabilidad;34k50;cota superior
abstract: This paper deals with finite-gain stabilization of linear systems by static feedbacks which are bounded and time-delayed. For neutrally stable continuous-time linear systems, we provide a saturated linear feedback law ensuring finite-gain stability with respect to every $L^p$-norm, $p \in [1, \infty]$, with an arbitrary small bound on the control and large (constant) delay. Moreover, we provide upper bounds for the corresponding $L^p$-gains which are delay-independent.
fos: lyapunov function;calculus;control theory;mathematics

title: analysis of incremental exponential stability for switched nonlinear systems
abstract: In this paper, we analyze stability of incremental exponential stability for switched nonlinear systems with time delay. The continuous contraction theory is generalized to introduce a new type of switching laws. On this basis, the incremental exponential stability is established for both stable and unstable subsystems within the overall switched nonlinear systems with time delay. Computer simulations are presented to validate the theoretical findings.
journal: 2018 IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems (ISCAS)
fos: control theory;computer science;nonlinear system;contraction (operator theory);exponential stability

title: global exponential stability for switched memristive neural networks with time-varying delays
keywords: switched system;exponential stability;memristive neural networks;average dwell time;linear matrix inequalities
abstract: This paper considers the problem of exponential stability for switched memristive neural networks (MNNs) with time-varying delays. Different from most of the existing papers, we model a memristor as a continuous system, and view switched MNNs as switched neural networks with uncertain time-varying parameters. Based on average dwell time technique, mode-dependent average dwell time technique and multiple Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional approach, two conditions are derived to design the switching signal and guarantee the exponential stability of the considered neural networks, which are delay-dependent and formulated by linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Finally, the effectiveness of the theoretical results is demonstrated by two numerical examples.

journal: Neural networks : the official journal of the International Neural Network Society

title: further results on the bounds of the zeros of quasi-critical polynomials
keywords: modular form;polynomials automatic control stability servomechanisms nonlinear systems robust control nonlinear control systems approximation methods robustness;systeme discret;zero de polynome;boundary value problems discrete time systems state feedback stability poles and zeros;temps lineaire;state feedback;zero of polynomial;discrete time systems;similar test;commande retour etat;discrete time;cero de funcion;tiempo lineal;stability;poles and zeros;necessary and sufficient condition;linear time;zero of function;cero de polinomio;schur stability zeros bounds quasicritical polynomials linear discrete time systems state feedback;bucle realimentacion estado;boundary value problems;sistema discreto;tiempo discreto;temps discret;state feedback control;zero de fonction;discrete time system;analytic function;discrete system
abstract: On the basis of the relationship of the mth power of a polynomial and its modular form (polynomial whose coefficients are the moduli of the coefficients of that polynomial), we derive a necessary and sufficient condition for the modulus of the mth power of a polynomial for contacting its modular form on the boundary of a disc. Combined with the result about distribution of zeros of analytic function, some new sufficient conditions are derived which give bounds of the absolute values of the roots of a quasi-critical polynomial. These results extend certain earlier similar tests for linear discrete-time systems. Finally, four examples are given to demonstrate the results, Example 2.1 gives a state feedback application, Examples 2.2 and 2.4 deal with r-stability, and Example 2.3 display that our theorems give better results when m increases but at the cost of increasing complexity.
fos: time complexity;pole–zero plot;polynomial matrix;discrete time and continuous time;mathematical analysis;discrete mathematics;symmetric polynomial;modular form;polynomial function theorems for zeros;stability;homogeneous polynomial;alternating polynomial;boundary value problem;analytic function;stable polynomial;wilkinson's polynomial;discrete system;degree of a polynomial;control theory;mathematics;monic polynomial;factorization of polynomials;matrix polynomial;minimal polynomial;characteristic polynomial;reciprocal polynomial;polynomial remainder theorem;square-free polynomial;polynomial

title: backstepping-forwarding control and observation for hyperbolic pdes with fredholm integrals
keywords: kernel;transforms control nonlinearities control system synthesis feedback fredholm integral equations hyperbolic equations observers partial differential equations;integral equations;spectral properties backstepping forwarding control approach hyperbolic pde fredholm integrals integral transform boundary controller construction observers first order hyperbolic pide strict feedback structure sufficient conditions backstepping forwarding transform;observers;laplace equations;transforms;mathematical model;transforms kernel equations mathematical model integral equations laplace equations observers
abstract: An integral transform is introduced which allows the construction of boundary controllers and observers for a class of first-order hyperbolic PIDEs with Fredholm integrals. These systems do not have a strict-feedback structure and thus the standard backstepping approach cannot be applied. Sufficient conditions for the existence of the backstepping-forwarding transform are given in terms of spectral properties of some integral operators and, more conservatively but easily verifiable, in terms of the norms of the coefficients in the equations. An explicit transform is given for particular coefficient structures. In the case of strict-feedback systems, the procedure detailed in this paper reduces to the well-known backstepping design. The results are illustrated with numerical simulations.
entities: boundary element method;coefficient;computer simulation;first-order predicate;formal verification;numerical analysis;whole earth 'lectronic link
