title: linear quadratic optimal control of time-varying systems with indefinite costs on hilbert spaces
keywords: sistema lineal;espace hilbert;lq control;infinite dimension;control optimo;riccati equation;systeme commande;sistema control;time varying;espacio hilbert;cost function;time varying systems;dimension infinie;derived equivalence;linear system;time varying system;hilbert space;optimal control;control system;control lq;system synthesis;equation riccati;mild evolution operator;synthese systeme;commande optimale;systeme parametre variable;linear quadratic;sintesis sistema;quadratic optimization;finite horizon;ecuacion riccati;sistema parametro variable;systeme lineaire;optimal control problem;dimension infinita;commande lq;linear quadratic optimal control problem
abstract: In this paper we consider time-varying linear systems on Hilbert spaces and study the linear quadratic optimal control problem with an indefinite performance criterion over an infinite time interval. An example shows that in contrast to the finite-dimensional situation, in general, the solvability of the optimal control problem does not imply the solvability of the associated integral Riccati equation. Using an operator theoretic approach towards the time-varying integral Riccati equation, we derive equivalent conditions for the solvability of both problems.
fos: linear-quadratic-gaussian control;mathematical optimization;linear-quadratic regulator;mathematical analysis;optimal control;control system;algebraic riccati equation;riccati equation;control theory;mathematics;linear system;hilbert space

title: synchronization of lurie system based on contraction analysis
keywords: uniformly negative definite;virtual system;partial contraction;contraction
abstract: In this paper, a new synchronization criterion for chaotic Lurie systems with sector and slope restricted nonlinearities is proposed. Without analyzing the stability of the error system, synchronization condition for general Lurie systems is firstly given based on the contraction analysis. Furthermore, the result is extended to the Chua's system whose state equation is not differentiable. Finally, three representative examples are presented to support the theoretical results.
fos: calculus;control theory;contraction;mathematics

title: small-gain theorems of lasalle type for hybrid systems
keywords: lyapunov methods;lyapunov methods asymptotic stability feedback interconnected systems;interconnected systems;quantized control lasalle type hybrid systems feedback interconnections small gain analysis framework weak iss lyapunov functions asymptotic stability feedback systems event triggered control;asymptotic stability;feedback;lyapunov methods asymptotic stability stability analysis time domain analysis trajectory quantization educational institutions
abstract: We study stability of hybrid systems described as feedback interconnections of smaller subsystems, within a Lyapunov-based ISS small-gain analysis framework. We focus on constructing a weak (nonstrictly decreasing) Lyapunov function for the overall hybrid system from weak ISS-Lyapunov functions for the subsystems in the interconnection. Asymptotic stability of the hybrid system is then concluded by applying results of LaSalle type. The utility of this approach is illustrated on feedback systems arising in event-triggered control and quantized control.
journal: 2012 IEEE 51st IEEE Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;control-lyapunov function;lyapunov function;engineering;lyapunov equation;control theory;feedback;mathematics;lyapunov redesign;lyapunov exponent

title: continuous attractors of recurrent neural networks with complex-valued weights
keywords: global asymptotic stability;multi stability continuous attractors complex valued neural networks global exponential stability global asymptotic stability;recurrent neural nets asymptotic stability matrix algebra;matrix algebra;global exponential stability;asymptotic stability;mathematical model neurons recurrent neural networks asymptotic stability educational institutions brain modeling stability analysis;continuous attractors;connected matrix continuous attractors recurrent neural networks complex valued weights global exponential stability global asymptotic stability multistability continuous attractors infinite equilibria;recurrent neural nets;complex valued neural networks;multi stability
abstract: The global exponential stability (GAS), global asymptotic stability (GES) and multi-stability (MS) continuous attractors of recurrent neural networks (RNN) with complex-valued weights are studied in this paper. As a continuous attractor is the infinite equilibria, the connected matrix needs to be nonsingular. Therefore, RNN is transformed into a lower dimensional RNN using elementary operation. Firstly, based on the foregoing results some continuous attractors of RNN with real-valued weights are obtained. Secondly, continuous attractors of RNN with complex-valued weights are obtained by studying the corresponding RNN with real-valued weights. Some simulations are finally carried out to illustrate the theory.
entities: artificial neural network;random neural network;recurrent neural network;simulation;time complexity
journal: The 2012 International Joint Conference on Neural Networks (IJCNN)
fos: mathematical optimization;discrete mathematics;control theory;mathematics;exponential stability

title: costate approximation from direct methods for switched systems with state jumps
keywords: switched systems;convergence;switching systems control approximation theory optimal control;optimal control;trajectory;switches optimal control approximation methods trajectory switched systems convergence;approximation methods;switches;fixed switching sequence costate trajectory approximation direct method switched systems state jump optimal control problem
abstract: This paper demonstrates, how an approximation of the costate trajectory can be obtained for switched systems with state jumps, when an optimal control problem with fixed switching sequence is solved using a direct method, i.e. direct shooting or collocation. The obtained trajectories include the jump conditions for the costate given by necessary conditions for optimal control of switched systems.
entities: algorithm;approximation;collocation;direct method in the calculus of variations;optimal control
authors: Markus Schori;Thomas J. Böhme;Torsten Jeinsch;Bernhard P. Lampe
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;costate equations;control theory;mathematics

title: fixed-time synchronization of memristor-based bam neural networks with time-varying discrete delay
keywords: bam neural networks;delays;fixed-time synchronization;memristor
abstract: This paper is devoted to studying the fixed-time synchronization of memristor-based BAM neural networks (MBAMNNs) with discrete delay. Fixed-time synchronization means that synchronization can be achieved in a fixed time for any initial values of the considered systems. In the light of the double-layer structure of MBAMNNs, we design two similar feedback controllers. Based on Lyapunov stability theories, several criteria are established to guarantee that the drive and response MBAMNNs can realize synchronization in a fixed time. In particular, by changing the parameters of controllers, this fixed time can be adjusted to some desired value in advance, irrespective of the initial values of MBAMNNs. Numerical simulations are included to validate the derived results.
journal: Neural networks : the official journal of the International Neural Network Society
fos: memristor;artificial neural network;synchronization;lyapunov stability;computer science;control theory

title: dynamical reconstruction of unknown inputs in nonlinear differential equations
keywords: equation differentielle;reconstruccion senal;bounded variation;signal entree;differential equation;discrete time;dynamic method;ecuacion diferencial;identificacion sistema;input signal;senal entrada;system identification;methode dynamique;systeme non lineaire;nonlinear differential equation;metodo dinamico;signal reconstruction;reconstruction signal;nonlinear system;tiempo discreto;temps discret;sistema no lineal;non linear system;identification systeme
abstract: Abstract   We present an algorithm for the identification of an unknown but bounded input to a nonlinear finite-dimensional system, based on observations taken at discrete time instants and corrupted by observation errors. This algorithm is stable with respect to observation and computational errors.  If we have the further information that the unknown input is a signal of bounded variation, then we can give explicit convergence estimates of the algorithm.
fos: signal reconstruction;bounded variation;mathematical optimization;system identification;nonlinear system;calculus;control theory;mathematics;differential equation;quantum mechanics

title: robust stability of delayed fuzzy cohen-grossberg neural networks
keywords: fuzzy cohen grossberg neural networks;cohen grossberg neural network;robust stability;linear matrix inequality;time varying delay;delays;neural network
abstract: In this paper, using a linear matrix inequality and a differential inequality, we obtain an exponentially robust stability criterion for interval fuzzy Cohen-Grossberg type neural networks with time-varying delays. The criterion can be easily applied to the design of fuzzy general neural networks.
fos: mathematical optimization;types of artificial neural networks;linear matrix inequality;machine learning;control theory;mathematics;artificial neural network

title: norm-based capacity control in neural networks
abstract: We investigate the capacity, convexity and characterization of a general family of norm-constrained feed-forward networks.
fos: mathematical optimization;artificial intelligence;machine learning;artificial neural network;mathematics;norm (social);convexity

title: further results on exponential stability of linear discrete-time systems with time-varying delay
keywords: stability criteria;numerical stability;control theory;lmi exponential stability problem discrete time system interval time varying delay lyapunov krasovskii method lyapunov krasovskii functionals augmented vector reciprocally convex approach delay decomposition technique improved delay dependent condition linear matrix inequalities;delays control theory numerical stability stability criteria discrete time systems;discrete time systems;time varying systems asymptotic stability convex programming delays discrete time systems linear matrix inequalities linear systems lyapunov methods;conference proceeding;delays
abstract: This note addresses the exponential stability problem of a class of discrete-time systems with interval time-varying delay. Based on the Lyapunov-Krasovskii method, a set of appropriate Lyapunov-Krasovskii functionals, containing an augmented vector and some triple summation terms is first proposed. By utilizing the combination of the reciprocally convex approach and the delay-decomposition technique, improved delay-dependent conditions for exponential stability of the system are derived in terms of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Numerical examples are given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.
entities: linear matrix inequality;lyapunov fractal;numerical method;time complexity;triple des
authors: Nguyen D. That;Pham Cuong;Q. P. Ha
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;control theory;mathematics;exponential stability

title: synchronization in an array of nonidentical neural networks with leakage delays and impulsive coupling
keywords: leakage delay;impulsive coupling;nonidentical nodes;robust synchronization;neural network
abstract: This paper investigates robust and global exponential synchronizations in an array of nonidentical neural networks with leakage delays and impulsive coupling subject to parametric uncertainties. Some simpler sufficient conditions for synchronization are obtained when uncertainties vanish. A numerical example is given to illustrate the effectiveness of the theoretical results.
fos: real-time computing;computer science;machine learning;control theory;artificial neural network

title: robust stability of a class of hybrid nonlinear systems
keywords: lyapunov function;discrete time systems;discrete time systems hybrid nonlinear systems lyapunov functions sufficient conditions stability;indexing terms;stability;robust stability nonlinear systems lyapunov method communication system control chaotic communication control systems differential equations sufficient conditions circuits automatic control;robust stability;nonlinear systems;control system analysis;control system analysis nonlinear systems discrete time systems stability;nonlinear system
abstract: We analyze the discrete behavior to identify all kinds of cycles of hybrid nonlinear systems and then study the continuous behavior along each kind of cycle. Based on these analysis, we construct some continuous functions to bound Lyapunov functions along all subsystems and identify a subsequence of time points where the Lyapunov functions are non-increasing. We use these results to derive some new sufficient conditions for the robust stability of a class of hybrid nonlinear systems with polytopic uncertainties. These conditions do not require the Lyapunov functions to be non-increasing along each subsystem nor the whole sequence of the switching. Furthermore, they do not require the knowledge of continuous trajectory.
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;index term;stability;sliding mode control;nonlinear system;lyapunov function;lyapunov equation;control theory;mathematics;lyapunov redesign;circle criterion;lyapunov exponent

title: global lagged finite-time synchronization of two chaotic lur'e systems subject to time delay
keywords: chaos;期刊论文;lur e system;finite time synchronization;chua s oscillator;variable substitution and feedback controller
abstract: This paper investigates the global lagged finite-time synchronization of the master-slave Lur’e systems subject to time delay of signal transmission. By designing a variable-substitution and feedback controller, a master-slave finite-time synchronization scheme for the Lur’e systems with time delay is built up. Two delay-independent global lagged finite-time synchronization criteria are proved in the forms of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs), and the corresponding settling time of synchronization is analytically estimated. The obtained LMI criteria are applied to Chua’s oscillators, obtaining some easily implemented algebraic criteria under various single-variablesubstitution and feedback controller, which are then optimized to improve their conservative property. Finally, several numerical examples are illustrated to verify the effectiveness of the optimized criteria.
entities: broadcast delay;chua's circuit;control theory;digraphs and trigraphs;feedback;linear algebra;linear matrix inequality;master/slave (technology);nl (complexity);nl-complete;numerical analysis;numerical aperture;settling time
fos: real-time computing;control theory;mathematics

title: equilibrium capacity of analog feedback neural networks
keywords: etude theorique;circuito analogico;upper bound;analog circuit;retroaccion;retroaction;equilibrium condition;multimodal sigmoidal functions equilibrium capacity analog feedback neural networks stable equilibria self feedback coefficients;neurofeedback neural networks upper bound nonlinear dynamical systems hopfield neural networks image storage associative memory recurrent neural networks feedforward neural networks emulation;estudio teorico;feedback regulation;condition equilibre;recurrent neural nets;theoretical study;reseau neuronal;red neuronal;circuit analogique;condicion equilibrio;neural network
abstract: A method for estimating the equilibrium capacity of a general class of analog feedback neural networks is presented in this brief paper. Some explicit relationships between upper bound of the number of possible stable equilibria and the network parameters such as self-feedback coefficients, weights, and gains of a feedback neural network are obtained. Increasing the equilibrium capacity using multimodal sigmoidal functions is also discussed. Some examples are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the analytical results presented.
fos: analogue electronics;computer science;artificial intelligence;machine learning;control theory;upper and lower bounds;artificial neural network

title: necessary and sufficient conditions for bibo-stability of some fractional delay systems of neutral type
keywords: sistema bibo;transfer functions;neutral type fractional delay systems bibo stability bounded input bounded output stability;condition necessaire suffisante;computer model;bounded input bounded output stability;bounded input bounded output bibo stability;delay effects;sistema neutro;fractional order systems;neutral type systems;delay system;indexing terms;sufficient conditions;polynomials;fractional derivative;derivee fractionnaire;stability delays;stability;neutral system;fractional delay;bounded input bounded output;computational modeling;systeme a retard;transfer function;systeme bibo;neutral type fractional delay systems;necessary and sufficient condition;bibo system;delay systems;sistema con retardo;systeme neutre;electrical engineering;bibo stability;large classes;derivada fracionario;condicion necesaria suficiente;neutral type systems bounded input bounded output bibo stability delay systems fractional order systems;delay systems sufficient conditions polynomials electrical engineering delay effects computational modeling transfer functions;delays;type system
abstract: In this note, bounded-input bounded-output (BIBO)-stability of a large class of neutral type fractional delay systems is investigated. Necessary and sufficient conditions of BIBO-stability are presented for the intended class of systems (the sufficient conditions have been provided for a more general case in the previous studies). Two lemmas are provided for checking a prerequisite imposed on the considered class of systems. Finally, two numerical examples are given to illustrate the obtained results.
entities: bibo stability;numerical analysis;type system;verification and validation
fos: computer simulation;control engineering;mathematical optimization;control theory;mathematics;transfer function

title: a note on delay robustness for homogeneous systems with negative degree
keywords: homogeneous systems;application of nonlinear analysis and design;systems with time delays
abstract: Robustness with respect to delays is discussed for homogeneous systems with negative degree. It is shown that if homogeneous system with negative degree is globally asymptotically stable at the origin in the delay-free case then the system is globally asymptotically stable with respect to a compact set containing the origin independently of delay. The possibility of applying the result for local analysis of stability for not necessary homogeneous systems is analyzed. The theoretical results are supported by numerical examples.
authors: Konstantin Zimenko;Denis V. Efimov;Andrei Polyakov;Wilfrid Perruquetti
fos: mathematical optimization;discrete mathematics;control theory;mathematics

title: optimal control via initial conditions of a time delay hyperbolic system with the neumann boundary condition
keywords: dirichlet boundary condition;linear systems;boundary conditions;quadratic form;constrained control;dirichlet problem;delay effects;time delay;delay equation;optimal control;optimization problem;boundary condition;necessary and sufficient condition;hyperbolic equations;distributed parameter system;initial condition;hyperbolic system;optimization;optimal control equations delay effects boundary conditions optimization educational institutions delay;boundary value problems;optimal control boundary value problems delays distributed control hyperbolic equations linear systems;existence and uniqueness;necessary conditions optimal control time delay hyperbolic system optimization problems distributed hyperbolic systems linear hyperbolic system multiple time delays sufficient conditions hyperbolic equations dirichlet boundary conditions lions scheme;distributed control;hyperbolic equation;delays;optimal control problem
abstract: Various optimization problems associated with the optimal control of distributed hyperbolic systems with time delays appearing in the boundary conditions have been studied recently in Refs. [2]-[7] respectively. In this paper, we consider an optimal control problem for a linear hyperbolic system in which multiple time delays appear in the state equation. The initial conditions are given by control functions. Sufficient conditions for the existence of a unique solution of such hyperbolic equations with the Neumann boundary conditions are presented. The performance functional has the quadratic form. The time horizon T is fixed. Finally, we impose some constraints on the control. Making use of the Lions scheme [8], necessary and sufficient conditions of optimality for the Neumann problem with the quadratic performance functional and constrained control are derived.
entities: broadcast delay;control function (econometrics);initial condition;mathematical optimization;optimal control
journal: 2013 18th International Conference on Methods & Models in Automation & Robotics (MMAR)
fos: mathematical optimization;optimal control;boundary value problem

title: new stability conditions for a class of linear time-varying systems
keywords: computacion informatica;non monotonic lyapunov functions;grupo de excelencia;asymptotic stability;ciencias basicas y experimentales;linear time varying systems;stability conditions
abstract: This paper considers the problem of asymptotic stability for linear time-varying systems of the form x ź ( t ) = A ( t ) x ( t ) . Some new stability conditions are proposed. First, two stability conditions for nonlinear time-varying systems are given by using non-monotonic Lyapunov functions. Then the results obtained are extended to the linear case, two stability conditions with infinite integral are derived. Furthermore, by using the top-floor function, a linear matrix inequalities (LMI) condition and an eigenvalue criterion for asymptotic stability of systems are presented. Comparing with the existing results, the conditions obtained allow both A ( t ) and A ź ( t ) are unbounded at t = + ∞ . Some numerical examples are provided to show the effectiveness of the theoretical results.
fos: mathematical optimization;engineering;stability conditions;calculus;control theory;mathematics;circle criterion

title: estimates of equilibrium points and global asymptotic stability of cohen-grossberg neural networks with delays
keywords: condicion existencia;distributed delay;global asymptotic stability;cohen grossberg neural network;point equilibre;activation function;stabilite asymptotique;localization;funcion actividad;localizacion;delay system;asymptotic stability;equilibrium point;punto equilibrio;condicion lipschitz;localisation;systeme a retard;fonction activation;condition lipschitz;retard;condition existence;lipschitz condition;sistema con retardo;estabilidad asintotica;reseau neuronal;retraso;existence condition;red neuronal;neural network
abstract: This article studies a class of Cohen–Grossberg neural networks (CGNNs) with variable and distributed delays. Some novel conditions guaranteeing the existence, uniqueness and the estimated location of the equilibrium points are obtained. Using these results, the global asymptotic stability of the CGNNs can be derived without demanding the boundedness and the globally Lipschitz condition of the activation functions. Two numerical examples are demonstrated to verify the theoretical results.
fos: equilibrium point;internationalization and localization;computer science;machine learning;calculus;control theory;mathematics;lipschitz continuity;mathematical economics;activation function;artificial neural network

title: convex computation of the maximum controlled invariant set for polynomial control systems
keywords: maximum controlled invariant set;semidefinite programming;nonlinear control;polynomial optimization;optimal control;moments;nonlinear systems;49m;49l;sum of squares;90c22;region of attraction;occupation measure
abstract: We characterize the maximum controlled invariant (MCI) set for discreteas well as continuous-time nonlinear dynamical systems as the solution of an infinitedimensional linear programming problem. For systems with polynomial dynamics and compact semialgebraic state and control constraints, we describe a hierarchy of finite-dimensional linear matrix inequality (LMI) relaxations whose optimal values converge to the volume of the MCI set; dual to these LMI relaxations are sum-ofsquares (SOS) problems providing a converging sequence of outer approximations to the MCI set. The approach is simple and readily applicable in the sense that the approximations are the outcome of a single semidefinite program with no additional input apart from the problem description. A number of numerical examples illustrate the approach.
entities: approximation;computation;converge;dynamical system;linear matrix inequality;linear programming;nonlinear system;numerical analysis;polynomial;semidefinite programming;social inequality
fos: mathematical optimization;combinatorics;discrete mathematics;invariant polynomial;optimal control;nonlinear control;nonlinear system;control theory;mathematics;moment;explained sum of squares;semidefinite programming

title: an improved robust stability result for uncertain neural networks with multiple time delays
keywords: delayed systems;lyapunov functionals;neural networks;stability analysis
abstract: This paper proposes a new alternative sufficient condition for the existence, uniqueness and global asymptotic stability of the equilibrium point for the class of delayed neural networks under the parameter uncertainties of the neural system. The existence and uniqueness of the equilibrium point is proved by using the Homomorphic mapping theorem. The asymptotic stability of the equilibrium point is established by employing the Lyapunov stability theorems. The obtained robust stability condition establishes a new relationship between the network parameters of the system. We compare our stability result with the previous corresponding robust stability results derived in the past literature. Some comparative numerical examples together with some simulation results are also given to show the applicability and advantages of our result.
entities: artificial neural network;class;kind of quantity - equilibrium;lyapunov fractal;neural network simulation;numerical analysis;numerical stability;population parameter
journal: Neural networks : the official journal of the International Neural Network Society
fos: mathematical optimization;von neumann stability analysis;computer science;machine learning;control theory;mathematics;mathematical economics;artificial neural network

title: global chaos synchronisation of identical chaotic systems via novel sliding mode control method and its application to zhu system
keywords: lyapunov stability theory;chaos;zhu system;smc;chaos synchronisation;chaotic systems;sliding mode control
abstract: Synchronisation of chaotic systems is an important research problem in chaos theory. In this research work, a novel sliding mode control method is proposed for the global chaos synchronisation of identical chaotic systems. The general result derived using novel sliding mode control method is established using Lyapunov stability theory. As an application of the general result, the problem of global chaos synchronisation of identical Zhu chaotic systems (2010) is studied and a new sliding mode controller is derived. Numerical simulations have been shown to illustrate the phase portraits of Zhu chaotic system and the sliding mode controller design for the global chaos synchronisation of identical Zhu chaotic systems.
entities: chaos theory;computational fluid dynamics;lyapunov fractal;numerical linear algebra;simulation
fos: control engineering;control of chaos;sliding mode control;engineering;control theory;mathematics;synchronization of chaos;distributed computing

title: stabilization of switched linear systems with mode-dependent time-varying delays
keywords: metodo lyapunov;sistema lineal;metodo directo;iterative method;multiple lyapunov functions;analisis numerico;37l45;switched system;matematicas aplicadas;funcion lyapunov;mathematiques appliquees;fonctionnelle lyapunov;65f05;lyapunov function;stabilization;temps lineaire;state feedback;lyapunov functional;tiempo lineal;delay system;matrix inversion;inversion matriz;linear system;funcional lyapunov;analyse numerique;condition suffisante;metodo iterativo;upper bound;14c20;feedback;lyapunov method;numerical analysis;linear matrix inequality;condicion suficiente;systeme a retard;fonction lyapunov;methode iterative;switched linear system;linear time;algebra lineal numerica;algebre lineaire numerique;inversion matrice;numerical linear algebra;sufficient condition;sistema con retardo;boucle reaction;time varying delay;systeme lineaire;switched linear delay system;borne superieure;applied mathematics;retroalimentacion;methode directe;methode lyapunov;65f10;37b25;direct method;cota superior
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the problem of stabilization via state feedback and/or state-based switching for switched linear systems with mode-dependent time-varying delays. By using the multiple Lyapunov functional method, we establish sufficient conditions that guarantee the switched system is stabilizable via state feedback and/or switching under time-varying delays with appropriate upper bounds. The main results are presented in terms of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) which generalize some known results and can be easily tested by using the Matlab’s LMI Tool-box.
fos: direct method;time complexity;linear matrix inequality;numerical analysis;lyapunov function;calculus;control theory;feedback;mathematics;iterative method;numerical linear algebra;linear system;upper and lower bounds

title: construction of lyapunov functionals for coupled differential and continuous time difference equations
keywords: lyapunov methods;integral input to state stability lyapunov functionals coupled differential equations continuous time difference equations stability analysis explicit construction iiss;lyapunov functional stability delay difference equation;stability continuous time systems difference equations lyapunov methods;stability;continuous time systems;difference equations;difference equations delays differential equations lyapunov methods trajectory stability criteria
abstract: A new stability analysis technique for systems composed of a differential equation coupled with a continuous time difference equation is proposed. It is based on the explicit construction of Lyapunov functionals from the knowledge of Lyapunov functions for subsystems. Robustness results of iISS type are inferred from these functionals.
journal: 52nd IEEE Conference on Decision and Control
fos: mathematical optimization;mathematical analysis;recurrence relation;stability;lyapunov function;lyapunov equation;control theory;mathematics;lyapunov redesign;stability theory;lyapunov exponent;lyapunov optimization;statistics

title: simultaneous finite- and infinite-zero assignments of linear systems
keywords: sistema lineal;assignment problem;systeme multivariable;canonical form;teoria sistema;asignacion cero;invariant zeros;linear multivariable systems;linear system;infinite zeros;systems theory;transfer function;funcion traspaso;theorie systeme;sistema multivariable;assignation zero;multivariable system;zero placement;fonction transfert;zero assignment;systeme lineaire;linear system theory;linear systems theory
abstract: A simultaneous finiteand infinite-zero assignment problem via sensor selection for linear multivariable systems is proposed. By sensor selection we mean an appropriate choice of the output matrix C. Here, by utilizing the well-known Bumovsky canonical form for a linear system characterized by the matrix pair (A, B), we obtain an explicit construction algorithm that generates a non-empty set Q of output matrices such that for any member C of this set, the corresponding system characterized by the triple (A, B, C) has the prescribed finiteand infinite-zero structures. Two examples are also given to illustrate our results.
entities: algorithm;assignment problem;linear system;the matrix;whole earth 'lectronic link
fos: canonical form;discrete mathematics;calculus;control theory;mathematics;assignment problem;transfer function;linear system;systems theory

title: stability of positive fractional continuous-time linear systems with delays
keywords: continuous time;positive;fractional;asymptotic stability;linear system;stability;necessary and sufficient condition
abstract: Necessary and sufficient conditions for the asymptotic stability of positive fractional continuous-time linear systems with delays are established. It is shown that: 1) the asymptotic stability of the positive fractional system is independent of their delays, 2) the checking of the asymptotic stability of the positive fractional systems with delays can be reduced to checking of the asymptotic stability of positive standard linear systems without delays.
fos: mathematical optimization;mathematical analysis;stability;control theory;linear system

title: backstepping boundary stabilization and state estimation of a 2 × 2 linear hyperbolic system
keywords: linear systems;kernel;goursat type backstepping boundary stabilization state estimation 2 2 linear hyperbolic system first order hyperbolic linear pde partial differential equations spatial varying coefficients full state feedback law exponential stability closed loop system collocated boundary observer collocated output feedback law backstepping method control kernels observer kernels;closed loop systems;boundary conditions;state feedback;exponential stability;observers;state estimation;asymptotic stability;output feedback;feedback;first order;backstepping;boundary condition;partial differential equations;hyperbolic equations;hyperbolic system;estimation error;kernel observers equations boundary conditions backstepping output feedback estimation error;partial differential equations asymptotic stability closed loop systems feedback hyperbolic equations linear systems observers
abstract: We consider the problem of boundary stabilization and state estimation for a 2×2 system of first-order hyperbolic linear PDEs with spatially varying coefficients. First, we design a full-state feedback law with actuation on only one end of the domain and prove exponential stability of the closed-loop system. Then, we construct a collocated boundary observer which only needs measurements on the controlled end and prove convergence of observer estimates. Both results are combined to obtain a collocated output feedback law. The backstepping method is used to obtain both control and observer kernels. The kernels are the solution of a 4 × 4 system of first-order hyperbolic linear PDEs with spatially varying coefficients of Goursat type, whose well-posedness is shown.
entities: block cipher mode of operation;coefficient;first-order predicate;first-order reduction;time complexity;well-posed problem
journal: IEEE Conference on Decision and Control and European Control Conference
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;boundary value problem;control theory;mathematics;exponential stability

title: robust h∞ control for uncertain discrete singular systems with pole placement in a disk
keywords: uncertain systems;singular system;discrete time;robust control;satisfiability;output feedback;singular systems;matrix inequalities;pole placement;dynamic output feedback;article;uncertain system
abstract: This paper addresses the design of robust H∞ controllers for uncertain discrete singular systems with time-invariant uncertainty in both the state and measurement matrices. The singular system to be controlled is not assumed to be regular. A regular dynamic output feedback controller is designed such that a prescribed H∞ performance condition is satis4ed and the closed-loop poles are placed in a speci4ed disk while the regularity, causality and stability of the closed-loop system can be guaranteed for all admissible uncertainties. The desired controller can be obtained by solving a set of matrix inequalities. A numerical example is given to demonstrate the application of the proposed method. c © 2001 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
entities: block cipher mode of operation;causality;control theory;numerical analysis;time-invariant system
fos: robust control;full state feedback;control engineering;mathematical optimization;discrete time and continuous time;control theory;mathematics;satisfiability

title: synchronization of chaos in nonlinear finance system by means of sliding mode and passive control methods: a comparative study
keywords: chaos synchronization;chaotic finance system;passive control;sliding mode control
abstract: In this paper, two different control methods, namely sliding mode control and passive control, are investigated for the synchronization of two identical chaotic finance systems with different initial conditions. Based on the sliding mode control theory, a sliding surface is determined. A Lyapunov function is used to prove that the passive controller provides global asymptotic stability of the system. Numerical simulations validate the synchronization of chaotic finance systems with the proposed sliding mode and passive control methods. The synchronization performance of these two methods is compared and discussed.
entities: control theory;initial condition;lyapunov fractal;simulation;synchronization of chaos
authors: Ugur Erkin Kocamaz;Alper Göksu;Harun Taskin;Yilmaz Uyaroglu
fos: simulation;sliding mode control;engineering;control theory;synchronization of chaos

title: nonlinear recurrent neural networks for finite-time solution of general time-varying linear matrix equations
keywords: finite-time convergence;general time-varying linear matrix equations;nonlinear activation functions;nonlinear recurrent neural networks
abstract: In order to solve general time-varying linear matrix equations (LMEs) more efficiently, this paper proposes two nonlinear recurrent neural networks based on two nonlinear activation functions. According to Lyapunov theory, such two nonlinear recurrent neural networks are proved to be convergent within finite-time. Besides, by solving differential equation, the upper bounds of the finite convergence time are determined analytically. Compared with existing recurrent neural networks, the proposed two nonlinear recurrent neural networks have a better convergence property (i.e., the upper bound is lower), and thus the accurate solutions of general time-varying LMEs can be obtained with less time. At last, various different situations have been considered by setting different coefficient matrices of general time-varying LMEs and a great variety of computer simulations (including the application to robot manipulators) have been conducted to validate the better finite-time convergence of the proposed two nonlinear recurrent neural networks.
journal: Neural networks : the official journal of the International Neural Network Society
fos: mathematics;mathematical optimization;differential equation;lyapunov function;nonlinear system;matrix (mathematics);recurrent neural network;convergence (routing);upper and lower bounds

title: robust exponential stability analysis for interval cohen-grossberg type bam neural networks with mixed time delays
abstract: In this paper, the robust exponential stability issue for the interval Cohen–Grossberg type BAM neural networks with nonsmooth behaved functions and mixed time delays is investigated. Firstly, based on Homomorphic mapping theory and nonsmooth analysis approach, the existence and uniqueness of the equilibrium point are proved. Secondly, by applying linear matrix inequality (LMI), free-weighting matrix technique, and available Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional method, some delaydependent conditions are achieved in terms of LMIs to ensure the considered neural network to be globally robustly exponentially stable. The results obtained in this paper are little conservative compared with the previous results in the literature. Finally, two simulation examples are given to illustrate the validity of the theoretical results.
entities: artificial neural network;linear matrix inequality;lyapunov fractal;simulation;social inequality;subderivative;time complexity
fos: mathematical optimization;discrete mathematics;control theory;mathematics

title: stabilisation of second-order lti switched positive systems
keywords: second order;switched positive systems;stabilisation problem;positive system;geometric approach;necessary and sufficient condition;geometrical approach;vector field;saddle point
abstract: The stabilisation problem of second-order switched positive systems consisting of two unstable subsystems is considered in this article. By considering the vector fields and geometric characteristics, a necessary and sufficient condition for the stabilisability of second-order switched positive systems with two unstable subsystems is provided. Furthermore, it is shown via this condition that neither second-order switched positive systems consisting of two subsystems with unstable nodes nor second-order switched positive systems consisting of one subsystem with unstable nodes and the other with a saddle point can be stabilised via any switching law.
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;vector field;control theory;mathematics;saddle point;second-order logic

title: a new parameterization of stable polynomials
keywords: optimisation;robust control;indexing terms;polynomials uncertain systems frequency domain analysis control systems feedback equations stability analysis robustness;polynomials;stability;robust stability;feedback;parameter uncertainty;feedback system;feedback polynomials stability robust control optimisation;parameter uncertainty stable polynomials parameterization ordered numbers stable degree n monic polynomial ordered frequencies monic polynomials stabilizing fixed order proper controllers unity feedback systems stability margin lower bounds robust control;lower bound
abstract: In this note, we develop a new characterization of stable polynomials. Specifically, given positive, ordered numbers (frequencies), we develop a procedure for constructing a stable degree monic polynomial with real coefficients. This construction can be viewed as a mapping from the space of ordered frequencies to the space of stable degree monic polynomials. The mapping is one–one and onto, thereby giving a complete parameterization of all stable, degree monic polynomials. We show how the result can be used to generate parameterizations of stabilizing fixedorder proper controllers for unity feedback systems. We apply these results in the development of stability margin lower bounds for systems with parameter uncertainty.
authors: Theodore E. Djaferis;David L. Pepyne;David M. Cushing
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;resultant;control theory;feedback;mathematics

title: high-order s-lemma with application to stability of a class of switched nonlinear systems
keywords: 90c26;strict homogeneous s lemma;93c10;homogeneous s lemma;70k20;nonhomogeneous s lemma;switched nonlinear system;lyapunov function with homogeneous derivative;convex combination
abstract: This paper extends some results on the S-Lemma proposed by Yakubovich and uses the improved results to investigate the asymptotic stability of a class of switched nonlinear systems. First, the strict S-Lemma is extended from quadratic forms to homogeneous functions with respect to any dilation, where the improved S-Lemma is named the strict homogeneous S-Lemma (SHS-Lemma). In detail, this paper indicates that the strict S-Lemma does not necessarily hold for homogeneous functions that are not quadratic forms, and proposes a necessary and sufficient condition under which the SHS-Lemma holds. It is well known that a switched linear system with two subsystems admits a Lyapunov function with homogeneous derivative (LFHD) if and only if it has a convex combination of the vector fields of its two subsystems that admits a LFHD. In this paper, it is shown that this conclusion does not necessarily hold for a general switched nonlinear system with two subsystems, and gives a necessary and sufficient condition under ...
fos: mathematical optimization;mathematical analysis;convex combination;homogeneous polynomial;control theory;mathematics

title: exponential convergence and lagrange stability for impulsive cohen-grossberg neural networks with time-varying delays
keywords: computacion informatica;lyapunov functions;lagrange stability;ciencias basicas y experimentales;matematicas;impulsive delay differential inequality;impulsive cohen grossberg neural networks;grupo a;exponential convergence
abstract: In this paper, the problem on exponential convergence and Lagrange exponential stability for a class of delayed Cohen-Grossberg neural networks with impulses effects is investigated. To this end, a new delay impulsive differential inequality is established, which improves and generalizes previously known criteria. By using the new inequality and coupling with the Lyapunov method, several sufficient conditions are derived to guarantee the global exponential stability in Lagrange sense and exponential convergence of the state variables of the discussed delayed Cohen-Grossberg neural networks with impulses effects. Meanwhile, the framework of the exponential convergence ball in the state space with a pre-specified convergence rate is also given. Here, the existence and uniqueness of the equilibrium points need not to be considered. Finally, some numerical examples with simulation show the effectiveness of the obtained results. We discuss Lagrange stability for impulsive Cohen-Grossberg neural networks.We establish a new delay impulsive differential inequality.Some easily verified conditions of Lagrange exponential stability are obtained.Giving out the detail estimations of the exponential convergence ball.The results here generalize and improve the earlier publications.
fos: mathematical optimization;mathematical analysis;lyapunov function;control theory;mathematics;exponential stability

title: asymptotic stability of fixed-point state-space digital filters with saturation arithmetic and external disturbance: an ioss approach
keywords: input output to state stability ioss;asymptotic stability;digital filter;saturation arithmetic;linear matrix inequality lmi;finite wordlength effect
abstract: A criterion for the input/output-to-state stability of interfered state-space digital filters with saturation arithmetic and external interference is presented. The proposed linear matrix inequality-based criterion ensures the reduction in the effect of external interference as well as confirms the asymptotic stability in the absence of external interference. The criterion turns out to be an improvement over a previously reported criterion. A numerical example is given to illustrate the applicability of the proposed criterion.
fos: mathematical optimization;discrete mathematics;digital filter;engineering;saturation arithmetic;jury stability criterion;control theory;mathematics;circle criterion

title: passivity-based integral sliding-mode control of uncertain singularly perturbed systems
keywords: uncertain systems;uncertainty;perturbation theory;variable structure systems;variable structure systems linear matrix inequalities perturbation theory uncertain systems;indexing terms;asymptotic stability;upper bound;linear matrix inequality lmi;sliding mode controller passivity based integral sliding mode control uncertain singularly perturbed systems integral sliding surface linear matrix inequality lmi closed loop system;singularly perturbed systems;linear matrix inequality;sliding mode control smc linear matrix inequality lmi passivity singularly perturbed systems;trajectory;sliding mode control smc;sliding mode controller;singularly perturbed system;passivity;sliding mode;switches;linear matrix inequalities;switches uncertainty linear matrix inequalities sliding mode control trajectory asymptotic stability upper bound;sliding mode control
abstract: This brief is concerned with passivity-based integral sliding-mode control of uncertain singularly perturbed systems. First, a proper integral sliding surface is constructed. Then, a sufficient condition in terms of linear matrix inequality (LMI) is derived under which the resulting closed-loop system is passive and asymptotically stable in the specified switching surface. The gain matrix of the sliding mode is achieved by means of the previous LMI. In addition, a sliding-mode controller is synthesized to guarantee the reachability of the specified sliding surface. Finally, a numerical example is provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the developed theoretical results.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
fos: control engineering;mathematical optimization;index term;uncertainty;sliding mode control;linear matrix inequality;network switch;trajectory;perturbation theory;control theory;mathematics;upper and lower bounds
